          Thanks Rick! You seem to have put alot of thought and time into t=
hat. 

                         What really bothers me is the self proclaim=
ed experts out there that take all evidence and experience and try to make =
it negative, and evil. Maybe many get tired, or even affraid of seeking par=
anormal experience for that reason.

                         I don't do gh=
ost hunts or invesitgations, but the hauntings I've heard of seem to be not=
hing more than something trying to get someone's attention. It's these expe=
rts that turn it into something that must be negative.  There's Hollywood, =
such as the "Haunting In CT", these same experts will proclaim is based on =
fact, when the facts are probably nothing more than your creaking floors, j=
ust to make the whole paranoramal field dark and demon filled. In my case, =
fear does not sell, I won' watch those movies. 

                         I=
 think there is good EVP evidence, and I've heard many from various researc=
hers.  Trouble is, it's like talking on a phone or radio, how do you know w=
ho it is other by what they say?

       =
                 On Sat, Apr 4, 2009 at 2:47 PM, Rick <rasterer@yahoo. com>=
 wrote:

                          --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com, "purple=
spacefriend" <purplealiengirl@ ...> wrote:

                          > Jus=
t wondering, seemed like interest in EVP/ITC was dropping off. Too bad the =
interest in EVP doesn't pick up while that ghost hunting mentality drops of=
f. I keep saying, you'll get better, more consistent, and more meaningful m=
essages if you record at home. The ghosts, spirits and entities can and do =
travel. You also have to listen to the recordings more than once. 
        =
                  > 
                          > Frank

                   =
       That is an interesting observation. I think the core of the issue is=
 that there seems to be a `sweet spot' in paranormal beliefs where there is=
 just enough science, just enough technical backing, just enough paranormal=
 claims, and just enough indefinite evidence that keeps people interested i=
n the ghost hunting mentality

                          Evidence which bec=
omes too indefinite turns off most people. As they become more aware of sen=
sitives who simply make claims ("I feel there is a GHOST here!"), but provi=
de no evidence other than statements, people eventually get bored. Similarl=
y, people eventually grow tired of the anthropomorphism of every little occ=
urrence in a house: a creak implies a footstep, which implies a person, whi=
ch, if not seen, implies a ghost. But a creak does not equal a footstep.

 =
                         And while this kind of indefinite evidence can los=
e an audience, so can evidence that is claimed to be "obviously" evident by=
 technology. Here, the investigator is no longer making vague claims, but w=
aving science around, like FLIR cameras, or EMF meters, and then making pro=
clamations of the results. But again, people eventually see these are just =
lights and sounds from electronics, and investigators making more claims. I=
t's like the psychics again, but with visual aids.

                       =
   I think the reason EVP studies are not securing more interest, as you no=
ted, are a little of both effects. First is the anthropomorphism problem: I=
 notice many EVP experimenters proclaim what their results sound like, or n=
ame the sound file by what they've heard. But like the creaks, "sounds like=
" does not equal "is". This is then compounded by the technology backing: r=
egardless of how valid the EVP researcher's results are, the technology can=
 seem intimidating, but the researchers often proclaim the obviousness of t=
heir results. People again become turned off by it because it is not obviou=
s to them, and in the end it is just another piece of technology presenting=
 sounds, with no obvious connection to the paranormal, except by the claims=
 and interpretations of the presenters.

                          I believ=
e, taking these issues into account, there is a way for EVP studies to garn=
er more interest. For now, the analysis coming from the researchers usually=
 seems like a claim, and it is these claims, imho, that is being classified=
 by the public with the rest of the paranormal claims, and so, it also beco=
mes less of an interest. A new approach could be one without the claims and=
 interpretations of the investigators, one where the sounds are simply play=
ed and not labeled. The interpretation of the data could be left to the lis=
teners. Web sites which present EVPs could be developed where people could =
not see others interpretations until they entered their own. I think this w=
ould be such a novel approach, that it would give the public a better feeli=
ng of true involvement in the research, and feel less like they are simply =
being exposed to the claims of others. And I think that feeling of involvem=
ent is what is needed to reignited the public interest here.
